intro: Pulsatilla pratensis subsp. montana, commonly known as the alpine pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, showy, cup-shaped flowers that typically bloom in early spring. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes and is adapted to grow in rocky or alpine soils. It is often found in open meadows and alpine tundra, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species in many regions.
